Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Observing and Modeling Downslope-windstorm-type Flow in a Small-scale Crater Induced by Larger-scale Katabatic Winds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This effort will investigate downslope windstorm-type flows (DWF) that have important societal effects and are poorly understood scientifically. The program includes a one-month field program at Arizona's Barringer Meteorite Crater and simulations with a Large-Eddy-Simulation (LES) model. A serendipitous discovery in a prior NSF-funded research program identified this location as being ideally suited for such a study, as DWFs develop there regularly when thermally driven drainage flows cascade over the crater's rim on clear, undisturbed nights. The crater's rim and environs are on a scale that can be readily instrumented to investigate these flows and the changing upstream conditions that cause them to form. DWFs are produced intermittently on the upwind inner sidewall of the small, circular crater basin as pulsations occur in the temperature and wind profiles of the approaching flow. This effort will thus support a systematic investigation of DWFs at a location where many replications can be expected over a comparatively short period.

An associated field effort during Autumn 2013 will collect data uniquely suited to support analyses to answer extant scientific questions about atmospheric DWFs produced by density-stratified flow over topography. Detailed sampling of atmospheric boundary layer conditions by multiple LiDAR (Light Detection And Ranging) and SoDAR (SOnic Detection And Ranging) platforms, tethered balloon sounding systems, as well as infrared time-lapse cameras and surface-based meteorological instrumentation, will be utilized. The overarching goal of the coordinated field research, analysis, and large-eddy simulation (LES) modeling to be conducted by this collaborative team is to determine the characteristic atmospheric structure and evolution associated with the DWFs, identify controlling parameters in the katabatic winds that drive DWFs and, through the modeling studies, extend the findings to basins and ridges of different size and shape to gain a more general understanding of DWFs. The intellectual merit of this research rests in application of novel and innovative concepts that will culminate in more comprehensive analyses and modeling informed by field experience, a short climatology, and initial analyses and simulations. These efforts will advance understanding of the physical processes that affect atmospheric DWF development in complex terrain, and are expected to lead to improvements in models and understanding of this ubiquitous phenomenon, which occurs in mountainous regions throughout the world.

Broader Impacts of this effort will include support of undergraduate and graduate student training, development of modules for classroom teaching, and early-career development of a postdoctoral researcher. Potential benefits to society will accrue through improved understanding of atmospheric DWFs with potential applications for forecasting of downslope windstorms, air pollution dispersion, general and fire weather forecasting, and climate. Results will be widely disseminated through peer-reviewed scientific publications, presentations at scientific meetings, and related websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This atmospheric research project, which combined field observations with analytical, numerical and conceptual modeling, investigated atmospheric flows that occur regularly in and around Arizona's Meteor Crater during nighttime when a temperature inversion forms on the adjacent extensive tilted plain and a layer of cold air drains down the plain. This drainage flow, which is deeper than most drainage flows studied to date, has different turbulence characteristics and leads to a variety of flow features as it interacts with the crater and its elevated rim.


The circular basin of the Meteor Crater was an ideal venue for observing these atmospheric circulation features, which have previously received little research attention. Collaborations with international research partners and with the private landowner of the Meteor Crater and the owners of ranch lands surrounding the crater led to an extensive field research program in October 2013 which obtained atmospheric data sets from 40- and 50-m high instrumented towers, thermal infrared imagers, wind lidars, a sodar, a scintillometer, tethered balloons, rawinsondes, short towers, arrays of temperature and humidity data loggers and other surface instrumentation. These data, which are publicly available in long-term storage, promoted detailed analyses of the flow features, and supported extensive numerical model simulations.


The interaction of the downslope flow with the elevated rim of Meteor Crater led to flow bifurcations, bluff body separations, cold air intrusions into the crater basin, and atmospheric hydraulic jumps. The cold air intrusions excite regular wave-like "sloshing" oscillations or seiches within the crater, similar to those seen by hydrologists in lakes and bays. When the approaching flow becomes strong, a deep atmospheric wave forms in the lee of the upwind crater rim, bringing warm air intrusions down into the crater from elevations well above the crater rim. A detailed analysis allowed us to determine the evolution of the flow structures as drainage winds increased in speed and depth on the plain. The influence of larger-scale background flows above the crater were examined by analyzing data from multiple nights in different weather conditions.


Collaborations were established with national and international partners, and students were trained using the Meteor Crater data sets. Peer-reviewed research papers were the main research output, elucidating the roles of atmospheric stability within and outside the crater, the vertical structure of the approaching winds and the effects of the underlying topography on flow phenomena. Numerical simulations were used to extend the results to a range of topographical situations, incoming flow strengths and atmospheric stabilities. Existing theoretical hydraulic flow and fluid dynamics concepts were evaluated with the experimental data. 


The improved understanding of the evolution and structure of these flows is expected to have numerous practical outcomes, since these local and mesoscale flow features are ubiquitous in complex terrain settings. Wind turbine design, engineering and siting, for example, require better characterization of the vertical structure of turbulence in commonly occurring deep drainage flows. Transport and dispersion of air pollutants and smoke from forest fires depends on these complex flow characteristics. Hydraulic jumps and associated turbulent downslope flows are a feature of damaging downslope windstorms and the various flow features studied at Meteor Crater are similar to flow disturbances around other terrain obstacles and buildings.
